title: 104_s1960
content:
SECTION 1. DEFINITIONS. Definitions for the Federal Aviation Administration include terms like Administration, Administrator, air transportation, aircraft, function, and office. The term "Secretary" in the context refers to the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, must reorganize the Federal Aviation Administration within 180 days of this Act. Functions not directly related to air safety will be transferred to another office of the Department, with funds authorized for this purpose. Savings provisions are also included. (a) Legal documents shall continue until modified, terminated, or revoked by the President, Secretary, court, or operation of law if issued in the performance of transferred functions and in effect on enactment date. (b) Proceedings remain unaffected. The provisions of this Act do not affect any ongoing proceedings or applications before the Federal Aviation Administration. Orders, appeals, and payments will continue as if the Act had not been enacted until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. The Act does not affect ongoing proceedings before the Federal Aviation Administration. Any proceedings can be discontinued or modified under the same terms as if the Act had not been enacted. Suits initiated before the Act's enactment will proceed as usual. Actions against the FAA or its officers will not be affected by the Act. The Act allows for the continuation of administrative actions by the Department related to the promulgation of regulations by the Federal Aviation Administration, with the same effect as if the Act had not been enacted. SEC. 4. REFERENCES.

Reference in any other Federal law, Executive order, regulation, or any document relating to the Administrator and the Administration shall be deemed to refer to the Secretary and the Department, respectively.

SEC. 5. RECOMMENDED LEGISLATION.

Within 180 days of enactment, the Secretary must submit recommended legislation to Congress for technical and conforming amendments to reflect the changes made by this Act.
